title: 107_hr2715
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rim of the Valley Corridor Study Act". Findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that the greater Southern California metropolitan region, the second largest urban concentration in the US, has one of the lowest ratios of park-and-recreation-lands-per-thousand-population. Without action, this situation will worsen due to intense growth. The lack of park, recreation, and open space near the Southern California metropolitan region deprives residents of health benefits, reduced crime, and increased educational opportunities. The Rim of the Valley Corridor encircles the San. The Rim of the Valley Corridor surrounding the San Fernando and La Crescenta valleys provides significant scenic, environmental, recreational, educational, scientific, and economic assets to Southern California. These assets deserve increased protection for public benefit in the future. The Rim of the Valley Corridor, including various mountain ranges, contains endangered habitats and unique ecotones. A key feature is the escarpment of the San Gabriel Mountains. The Rim of the Valley Corridor in the area includes the escarpment of the San Gabriel Mountains within the Angeles National Forest, managed for watershed, recreational, and habitat values. Privately owned lands in the corridor provide additional scenic, environmental, and recreational values and should be protected through voluntary incentives. The State of California has adopted the Rim of the Valley Master Plan to protect natural resources, but lacks financial resources and expertise. The Rim of the Valley Master Plan in California aims to protect natural resources, but lacks financial resources and expertise. A study is proposed to establish the Rim of the Valley corridor as a unit of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a special resource study of the Rim of the Valley Corridor in Southern California to evaluate its national significance and feasibility of becoming part of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. The Secretary will conduct a study to evaluate the Rim of the Valley Corridor's national significance for potential inclusion in the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. Criteria from Public Law 91-383 will be used, and consultation with advisory committees will be regular. Establishment of an advisory committee. The Rim of the Valley Corridor and Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area Advisory Committee is established to advise the Secretary of the Interior on a study and recommend boundaries for a new recreation area. The Committee recommends boundaries for the Valley National Recreation Area, reflecting the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area and including the Rim of the Valley Corridor lands and interests. The Committee, as per Division 23 of the California Public Resources Code, must submit a recommendation to the Secretary of the Interior within 365 days, including maps of proposed boundaries for a Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area, with public participation. The Committee, as mandated by Division 23 of the California Public Resources Code, must recommend boundaries for the Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area within 365 days. Public participation in and comment on the recommendation is required. The Committee consists of 24 members appointed by the Secretary of the Interior, including 17 representatives of local governments in the vicinity of the recreation area. The Committee consists of representatives from various local government bodies in the vicinity of the Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area, including the mayor of Los Angeles, the board of supervisors of Los Angeles and Ventura counties, and city councils of Thousand Oaks, Agoura Hills, Westlake Village, Malibu, Calabasas, Burbank, and Glendale. The city councils of Calabasas, Burbank, Glendale, La Canada-Flintridge, Pasadena, Sierra Madre, South Pasadena, Santa Clarita, Moorpark, and the board of supervisors of Los Angeles county are part of the Committee representing local government bodies in the Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area. The city council of Moorpark and the board of supervisors of Los Angeles county, along with other local government bodies, represent unincorporated communities within the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor. This includes consultation with the Town Council of Altadena and the Crescenta Valley Town Council. Additionally, officials from the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area and Angeles National Forest are involved in the decision-making process. The stakeholders involved in the decision-making process for the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor include the Supervisor of the Angeles National Forest, the Superintendent of the Angeles District of the State of California Department of Parks and Recreation, the Director of the Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy, a representative of the Rancho Simi Recreation and Park District, and a representative of the Conejo Recreation and Park District. The Committee for the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor includes representatives from various districts and agencies. The Committee will select a chairperson and vice chairperson from its members. Members will not receive compensation but will be reimbursed for necessary expenses by the Secretary of the Interior. The Committee for the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor consists of representatives from different districts and agencies. Members serve without compensation but will be reimbursed for necessary expenses by the Secretary of the Interior. A quorum of 13 members is required for conducting business, and the Committee will terminate upon the submission of the special resources study to Congress.
